## Portfolio Beta with Multiple Divisions

```{r}
#| eval: true
#| results: asis
#| echo: false
#| warning: false
w1 <- rnorm(1, mean = 0.6, sd = 0.05)
w2 <- 1 - w1
b1 <- rnorm(1, mean = 1.3, sd = 0.1)
b2 <- rnorm(1, mean = 0.7, sd = 0.1)
```

An institutional investor holds two divisions of Aurora Technologies:  
- Division A weight = **`r round(w1*100,2)`**%, beta = **`r round(b1,2)`**  
- Division B weight = **`r round(w2*100,2)`**%, beta = **`r round(b2,2)`**  

::: {.question-block}
<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault();" style="display: flex; flex-direction: row; gap: 6px;">
  <label for="module4_num_q8a"><strong>1. What is the overall portfolio beta?</strong></label>
  <input type="number" id="module4_num_q8a" name="module4_num_q8a" style="width: 150px;"
         data-correct-answer=`r round(w1*b1 + w2*b2,2)` data-tolerance="0.01" />
</form>

<div id="feedback-module4_num_q8a" class="feedback" style="display:none;">
✅ Portfolio Beta = w<sub>A</sub>β<sub>A</sub> + w<sub>B</sub>β<sub>B</sub> = **`r round(w1*b1 + w2*b2,2)`**.  
This shows how different risk exposures combine in a weighted portfolio.
</div>
:::
